author: Grimms
text: Long, long ago, some two thousand years or so, there lived a rich man with a good and beautiful wife.

author: Grimms
text: They loved each other dearly, but sorrowed much that they had no children.

author: Grimms
text: So greatly did they desire to have one, that the wife prayed for it day and night, but still they remained childless.

author: Grimms
text: In front of the house there was a court, in which grew a juniper-tree.

author: Grimms
text: One winter"s day the wife stood under the tree to peel some apples, and as she was peeling them, she cut her finger, and the blood fell on the snow.

author: Grimms
text: "Ah," sighed the woman heavily, "if I had but a child, as red as blood and as white as snow," and as she spoke the words, her heart grew light within her, and it seemed to her that her wish was granted, and she returned to the house feeling glad and comforted.

author: Grimms
text: A month passed, and the snow had all disappeared; then another month went by, and all the earth was green.

author: Grimms
text: So the months followed one another, and first the trees budded in the woods, and soon the green branches grew thickly intertwined, and then the blossoms began to fall.

author: Grimms
text: Once again the wife stood under the juniper-tree, and it was so full of sweet scent that her heart leaped for joy, and she was so overcome with her happiness, that she fell on her knees.

author: Grimms
text: Presently the fruit became round and firm, and she was glad and at peace; but when they were fully ripe she picked the berries and ate eagerly of them, and then she grew sad and ill.

author: Grimms
text: A little while later she called her husband, and said to him, weeping.

author: Grimms
text: "If I die, bury me under the juniper-tree."

author: Grimms
text: Then she felt comforted and happy again, and before another month had passed she had a little child, and when she saw that it was as white as snow and as red as blood, her joy was so great that she died.

author: Grimms
text: Her husband buried her under the juniper-tree, and wept bitterly for her.

author: Grimms
text: By degrees, however, his sorrow grew less, and although at times he still grieved over his loss, he was able to go about as usual, and later on he married again.

author: Grimms
text: He now had a little daughter born to him; the child of his first wife was a boy, who was as red as blood and as white as snow.

author: Grimms
text: The mother loved her daughter very much, and when she looked at her and then looked at the boy, it pierced her heart to think that he would always stand in the way of her own child, and she was continually thinking how she could get the whole of the property for her.

author: Grimms
text: This evil thought took possession of her more and more, and made her behave very unkindly to the boy.

author: Grimms
text: She drove him from place to place with cuffings and buffetings, so that the poor child went about in fear, and had no peace from the time he left school to the time he went back.

author: Grimms
text: One day the little daughter came running to her mother in the storeroom, and said, "Mother, give me an apple."

author: Grimms
text: "Yes, my child," said the wife, and she gave her a beautiful apple out of the chest; the chest had a very heavy lid and a large iron lock.

author: Grimms
text: "Mother," said the little daughter again, "may not brother have one too?"

author: Grimms
text: The mother was angry at this, but she answered, "Yes, when he comes out of school."

author: Grimms
text: Just then she looked out of the window and saw him coming, and it seemed as if an evil spirit entered into her, for she snatched the apple out of her little daughter"s hand, and said, "You shall not have one before your brother."

author: Grimms
text: She threw the apple into the chest and shut it to.

author: Grimms
text: The little boy now came in, and the evil spirit in the wife made her say kindly to him, "My son, will you have an apple?" but she gave him a wicked look.

author: Grimms
text: "Mother," said the boy, "how dreadful you look!

author: Grimms
text: Yes, give me an apple."

author: Grimms
text: The thought came to her that she would kill him.

author: Grimms
text: "Come with me," she said, and she lifted up the lid of the chest; "take one out for yourself."

author: Grimms
text: And as he bent over to do so, the evil spirit urged her, and crash! down went the lid, and off went the little boy"s head.

author: Grimms
text: Then she was overwhelmed with fear at the thought of what she had done.

author: Grimms
text: "If only I can prevent anyone knowing that I did it," she thought.

author: Grimms
text: So she went upstairs to her room, and took a white handkerchief out of her top drawer; then she set the boy"s head again on his shoulders, and bound it with the handkerchief so that nothing could be seen, and placed him on a chair by the door with an apple in his hand.

author: Grimms
text: Soon after this, little Marleen came up to her mother who was stirring a pot of boiling water over the fire, and said, "Mother, brother is sitting by the door with an apple in his hand, and he looks so pale; and when I asked him to give me the apple, he did not answer, and that frightened me."

author: Grimms
text: "Go to him again," said her mother, "and if he does not answer, give him a box on the ear."

author: Grimms
text: So little Marleen went, and said, "Brother, give me that apple," but he did not say a word; then she gave him a box on the ear, and his head rolled off.

author: Grimms
text: She was so terrified at this, that she ran crying and screaming to her mother.

author: Grimms
text: "Oh!" she said, "I have knocked off brother"s head," and then she wept and wept, and nothing would stop her.

author: Grimms
text: "What have you done!" said her mother, "but no one must know about it, so you must keep silence; what is done can"t be undone; we will make him into puddings."

author: Grimms
text: And she took the little boy and cut him up, made him into puddings, and put him in the pot.

author: Grimms
text: But Marleen stood looking on, and wept and wept, and her tears fell into the pot, so that there was no need of salt.

author: Grimms
text: Presently the father came home and sat down to his dinner; he asked, "Where is my son?"

author: Grimms
text: The mother said nothing, but gave him a large dish of black pudding, and Marleen still wept without ceasing.

author: Grimms
text: The father again asked, "Where is my son?"

author: Grimms
text: "Oh," answered the wife, "he is gone into the country to his mother"s great uncle; he is going to stay there some time."

author: Grimms
text: "What has he gone there for, and he never even said goodbye to me!"

author: Grimms
text: "Well, he likes being there, and he told me he should be away quite six weeks; he is well looked after there."

author: Grimms
text: "I feel very unhappy about it," said the husband, "in case it should not be all right, and he ought to have said goodbye to me."

author: Grimms
text: With this he went on with his dinner, and said, "Little Marleen, why do you weep?

author: Grimms
text: Brother will soon be back."

author: Grimms
text: Then he asked his wife for more pudding, and as he ate, he threw the bones under the table.

author: Grimms
text: Little Marleen went upstairs and took her best silk handkerchief out of her bottom drawer, and in it she wrapped all the bones from under the table and carried them outside, and all the time she did nothing but weep.

author: Grimms
text: Then she laid them in the green grass under the junipertree, and she had no sooner done so, then all her sadness seemed to leave her, and she wept no more.

author: Grimms
text: And now the juniper-tree began to move, and the branches waved backwards and forwards, first away from one another, and then together again, as it might be someone clapping their hands for joy.

author: Grimms
text: After this a mist came round the tree, and in the midst of it there was a burning as of fire, and out of the fire there flew a beautiful bird, that rose high into the air, singing magnificently, and when it could no more be seen, the juniper-tree stood there as before, and the silk handkerchief and the bones were gone.

author: Grimms
text: Little Marleen now felt as lighthearted and happy as if her brother were still alive, and she went back to the house and sat down cheerfully to the table and ate.

author: Grimms
text: The bird flew away and alighted on the house of a goldsmith and began to sing:

author: Grimms
text: "My mother killed her little son; My father grieved when I was gone; My sister loved me best of all; She laid her kerchief over me, And took my bones that they might lie Underneath the juniper-tree Kywitt, Kywitt, what a beautiful bird am I!"

author: Grimms
text: The goldsmith was in his workshop making a gold chain, when he heard the song of the bird on his roof.

author: Grimms
text: He thought it so beautiful that he got up and ran out, and as he crossed the threshold he lost one of his slippers.

author: Grimms
text: But he ran on into the middle of the street, with a slipper on one foot and a sock on the other; he still had on his apron, and still held the gold chain and the pincers in his hands, and so he stood gazing up at the bird, while the sun came shining brightly down on the street.

author: Grimms
text: "Bird," he said, "how beautifully you sing!

author: Grimms
text: Sing me that song again."

author: Grimms
text: "Nay," said the bird, "I do not sing twice for nothing.

author: Grimms
text: Give that gold chain, and I will sing it you again."

author: Grimms
text: "Here is the chain, take it," said the goldsmith.

author: Grimms
text: "Only sing me that again."

author: Grimms
text: The bird flew down and took the gold chain in his right claw, and then he alighted again in front of the goldsmith and sang:

author: Grimms
text: "My mother killed her little son; My father grieved when I was gone; My sister loved me best of all; She laid her kerchief over me, And took my bones that they might lie Underneath the juniper-tree Kywitt, Kywitt, what a beautiful bird am I!"

author: Grimms
text: Then he flew away, and settled on the roof of a shoemaker"s house and sang:

author: Grimms
text: "My mother killed her little son; My father grieved when I was gone; My sister loved me best of all; She laid her kerchief over me, And took my bones that they might lie Underneath the juniper-tree Kywitt, Kywitt, what a beautiful bird am I!"

author: Grimms
text: The shoemaker heard him, and he jumped up and ran out in his shirtsleeves, and stood looking up at the bird on the roof with his hand over his eyes to keep himself from being blinded by the sun.

author: Grimms
text: "Bird," he said, "how beautifully you sing!"

author: Grimms
text: Then he called through the door to his wife: "Wife, come out; here is a bird, come and look at it and hear how beautifully it sings."

author: Grimms
text: Then he called his daughter and the children, then the apprentices, girls and boys, and they all ran up the street to look at the bird, and saw how splendid it was with its red and green feathers, and its neck like burnished gold, and eyes like two bright stars in its head.

author: Grimms
text: "Bird," said the shoemaker, "sing me that song again."

author: Grimms
text: "Nay," answered the bird, "I do not sing twice for nothing; you must give me something."

author: Grimms
text: "Wife," said the man, "go into the garret; on the upper shelf you will see a pair of red shoes; bring them to me."

author: Grimms
text: The wife went in and fetched the shoes.

author: Grimms
text: "There, bird," said the shoemaker, "now sing me that song again."

author: Grimms
text: The bird flew down and took the red shoes in his left claw, and then he went back to the roof and sang:

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
text: When he had finished, he flew away.

author: Grimms
text: He had the chain in his right claw and the shoes in his left, and he flew right away to a mill, and the mill went "Click clack, click clack, click clack."

author: Grimms

author: Grimms

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
text: And when he had finished his song, he spread his wings, and with the chain in his right claw, the shoes in his left, and the millstone round his neck, he flew right away to his father"s house.

author: Grimms
text: The father, the mother, and little Marleen were having their dinner.

author: Grimms
text: "How lighthearted I feel," said the father, "so pleased and cheerful."

author: Grimms
text: "And I," said the mother, "I feel so uneasy, as if a heavy thunderstorm were coming."

author: Grimms
text: But little Marleen sat and wept and wept.

author: Grimms
text: Then the bird came flying towards the house and settled on the roof.

author: Grimms
text: "I do feel so happy," said the father, "and how beautifully the sun shines; I feel just as if I were going to see an old friend again."

author: Grimms
text: "Ah!" said the wife, "and I am so full of distress and uneasiness that my teeth chatter, and I feel as if there were a fire in my veins," and she tore open her dress; and all the while little Marleen sat in the corner and wept, and the plate on her knees was wet with her tears.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
text: "Then I will go out too," she said, "and see if it will lighten my misery, for I feel as if the world were coming to an end."

author: Grimms
text: But as she crossed the threshold, crash! the bird threw the millstone down on her head, and she was crushed to death.

author: Grimms
text: The father and little Marleen heard the sound and ran out, but they only saw mist and flame and fire rising from the spot, and when these had passed, there stood the little brother, and he took the father and little Marleen by the hand; then they all three rejoiced, and went inside together and sat down to their dinners and ate.
